Pablo Escobar: Pablo Emilio Escobar Gaviria (1949-1993) was a Colombian drug lord and narcoterrorist, serving as the head of the Medellín Cartel in the late 20th century. He was one of the wealthiest criminals in history, amassing an estimated $30 billion USD during the span of his criminal activities.
George Bush: George Walker Bush (born July 6, 1946) served as the 43rd President of the United States from 2001 to 2009. Before his presidency, he was the Governor of Texas from 1995 to 2000.
Lionel Messi: Lionel Andrés Messi (born June 24, 1987) is an Argentine professional footballer widely regarded as one of the greatest players of all time. He has won numerous awards including multiple Ballon d'Or titles and led Argentina to victory in the 2022 FIFA World Cup.
Serena Williams: Serena Jameka Williams (born September 26, 1981) is a former American professional tennis player. She has been ranked singles world No. 1 by the Women's Tennis Association for 319 weeks and won 23 Grand Slam singles titles, the most by any player in the Open Era.
Usain Bolt: Usain St. Leo Bolt OJ CD OLY (born August 21, 1986) is a Jamaican former sprinter, widely considered to be the greatest sprinter of all time. He is a world record holder in the 100 metres, 200 metres, and 4 × 100 metres relay.
Michael Phelps: Michael Fred Phelps II (born June 30, 1985) is an American former competitive swimmer. He is the most successful and most decorated Olympian of all time with a total of 28 medals, including 23 gold medals.
Simone Biles: Simone Arianne Biles (born March 14, 1997) is an American artistic gymnast. With a combined total of 32 Olympic and World Championship medals, Biles is the most decorated American gymnast and is considered one of the greatest gymnasts of all time.
LeBron James: LeBron Raymone James Sr. (born December 30, 1984) is an American professional basketball player for the Los Angeles Lakers in the NBA. He is widely considered one of the greatest players in NBA history and is frequently compared to Michael Jordan in debates over the greatest basketball player of all time.
Cristiano Ronaldo: Cristiano Ronaldo dos Santos Aveiro GOIH ComM (born February 5, 1985) is a Portuguese professional footballer who plays as a forward. He is widely regarded as one of the greatest players of all time and has won numerous individual and team awards throughout his career.
Enron: Enron Corporation was an American energy company based in Houston, Texas. It was founded in 1985 and became one of the largest companies in the United States. Enron's scandal, revealed in 2001, involved systematic accounting fraud and corruption, leading to one of the largest bankruptcies in U.S. history and the dissolution of Arthur Andersen, one of the five largest audit and accountancy partnerships in the world.
Volkswagen: Volkswagen AG, a German multinational automotive manufacturing company, was involved in a major scandal known as 'Dieselgate'. In 2015, the company was found to have intentionally programmed turbocharged direct injection (TDI) diesel engines to activate their emissions controls only during laboratory emissions testing, allowing the vehicles to meet US standards during regulatory testing while emitting up to 40 times more NOx in real-world driving.
Theranos: Theranos was a privately held health technology corporation, initially touted as a breakthrough technology company. Founded in 2003 by Elizabeth Holmes, it claimed to have devised blood tests that required only very small amounts of blood. In 2015, medical research professors John Ioannidis and Eleftherios Diamandis, along with investigative journalist John Carreyrou, questioned the validity of Theranos' technology. The company was eventually exposed as a fraud, with its claims about the effectiveness and reliability of its blood testing technology proven false.
Wells Fargo: Wells Fargo & Company, an American multinational financial services company, was involved in a scandal that came to light in 2016. The company was found to have created millions of fraudulent savings and checking accounts on behalf of Wells Fargo clients without their consent. Various charges and fines were levied against the company, including a $3 billion fine in 2020 to settle potential federal criminal and civil charges.
Cambridge Analytica: Cambridge Analytica was a British political consulting firm which combined data mining, data brokerage, and data analysis with strategic communication during electoral processes. In early 2018, the company became embroiled in a scandal when it was revealed that it had harvested the personal data of millions of Facebook users without their consent, using it for political advertising purposes. This revelation led to government investigations and the company's eventual closure.
